div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7758] ALEXANDRIA, MONDAY, MAY 5, 1907. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS (Athens), SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
S.S. Osmanioh Thursday 11 a.m. May 9, 23, June 6 annd 20.
S.S. Ismallia Wednesday 4 p.m. May 1, 15, 29, June 12, and 26.

Fast steamers Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Mail Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Monday at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan, Suakin, Massoawah, Hasedah and Aden. For further information regarding the Co's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, Suez up to THOS. Cook Sons (Egypt) Ltd. Hammero Amerika Risk under Tourist Agencies.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. EXPECTED AT ALEXANDRIA.
S.S. Androos May 23 from Hamburg bound for Beyrout or about 15th most.
For tariff and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS, Alexandria, Agent.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: First-class Hotel. Situated in Rosetta Avenue, the finest quarter in the Town. Two mintes from Railway Station. Close to Conservatory and the Opera House. Lift. Electric Light Throughout. Perfect Sanitary Arrangements. Magnificent Ball, Reception, Reading, and Music Rooms. Bar and Smoking Room.
FINE TERRACE ON THE AVENUE. MEETS ALL TRAINS AND STEAMERS. MANAGER F REINSPERCER. 28-26

div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT RAILWAYS.
div.p: CAIRO-KHARTOUM SUMMER MAIL SERVICE.--SUMMER TIME-TABLE 1906.
Commencing from 1st of April, 1906, until further notice

‡Sleeping and Dining Cars. — During the month of April Sleeping and Dining Care trains leave Cairo for Luxor on Wednesdays, Mondays and Saturdays at 6.30 p.m. and Luxor for Cairo on Sundays, Tuesdays and Thursdays at 6.30 p.m.

From 1st of May 1908, these trains will be suppressed, but Dining and Sleeping Care will be attached to the ordinary night Tains from Cairo and Luxor three times a week, on the same above mentioned days. 14-6-907

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice Trieste. Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria Saturdays 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi Tuesdays 5 a.m. in time for Express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival at Venice Wednesday about 9.30 a.m. Passengers may proceed from Venice to Switzerland, Paris and London by the 2 p.m. and 11.5 p.m. – Expresses. Arrival at Trieste Wednesday about 3 p.m. in connection with the Train de Luxe proceeding the same evening to Vienna, Frankfort, Cologne, Brussel, Ostende and London. Arrival at London every Friday 5.12 p.m.
Special Train Service from Cairo Station to Alexandria Quay alongside steamer, Saturdays at 9.30 a.m.
Steamer leaves Alexandria every Thursday 10 a.m. On and from April 11th at 4 p.m.
Syrian-Cyprus Line. Beyrout, Limassol, Larnaca, Mersina, Febr. 26; March 12, 26 ; April 9. 23 ; May 7, 21 ; June 4, 18.

To Suez, Aden and Bombay accelerated service 22 Febr.; 7, 23 March ; 4, 23 April ; 8 May ; 8 June.

To Suez, Aden, Karachi, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about 18 Jan., 18 Feb., 18 March, 18 April, 18 May, 18 June. – For information apply to the Agents, Alexandria, Port Said, Suez, and Khartum.

div.head: Calvert's Carbolic Toilet Soap
div.p: Ensures a Clear, Soft Skin.

It is pure throughout, fragrantly perfumed, emollient, and antisceptic, (10% crystal carbolic). It quickly removes dust and dirt, takes away the unpleasant effects of perspiration, and leaves instead a delicious feeling of thorough purification.

p.hi: Sold by local Chemists and Storekeepers.

div.head: FORCE APRÈS MALADIE
div.p: De même que la plus petite graine peut donner naissance à un très grand arbre, le moindre rhume, la toux la plus légère peuvent engendrer une longue et dangereuse maladie s'ils ne sont, en temps opportun, enrayés à l'aide de l'Emulsion Scott.

Toutes affections de la gorge et la poitrine, de quelque nature et si opiniâtres, si anciennes qu'elles soient, cèdent rapidement à l'efficacité de
qui vous refait des poumons capables de résister à toute intempéries ou autres influences malfaisantes.
Quand les fièvres ou une longue et douloureuse maladie ont réduit le corps à un inquiétant état de faiblesse et d'amaigrissement, un reconstituant qui vous remettra promptement est nécessaire.
l'EMULSION SCOTT

est le meilleur fortifiant du monde: ell na pas d..... Ell stimule l'appétit et améliore promptement la digestion. Elle fait des muscles et enrichit le sang, ell .... vitalité et donne à l'organism le pouvoir de résister à la maladie. L'Emulsion Scott est autant un alanent .... remède, car ell fournit au corps affaibli ce dont il a besoin pour reprendre muscles et forces ; ses nombres..... faisant résultats sont, en vérité, surprenants. Il y a reclle...ment grand danger à perdre embonpoint et pois à l'organism, bientôt débilité, deviendrait une proie facile pour la maladie.
L'EMULSION SCOTT

contient le principe fortifiant de tous aliments ; elle arrête le déperissement et reconstitutue une chair saine. Le flaton en est toujour présenté dans une enveloppe de papier couleur saumon avec, dessus, cette gravure.
En vente chez tous Pharmaciens et Droguistes.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: NEW VICTORIA HOTEL,
div.p: Open all the year round.
San Stefano, Near Alexandria, Halt No. 2.

Specially built in 1904 for a class Hotel with every modern comfort. Magnificent Dining room, Saloons, Smoking room, largo Verandahs and Garden. Electric light. MODERATE CHARGES. Ten minutes by carriage or Palais tram from Sidi Gaber.—Special terms for Government Officials and Officers of the Army of Occupation. C. F. RAISIG. Manager.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: THE ENGLISH DAILY NEWSPAPER.
ESTABLISHED 1880.
Editor and Manager - - R. SNELLING.
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
MONDAY, MAY” 13, 1907.

div.head: "EMPIRE DAY.”
div.p: We are now within a short spell of an anniversary already endeared by moving and splendid memories to the British peoples throughout the world, and destined in the future, as we think, to be observed with universal consent as thefte-day of the Empi Upon May 24, 1819, “in a palace in a garden to recall the romantic phrase of her favor Minister, Queen Victoria was born under nobler horoscope than was in human insight to forecast. In personal excellence amd dign of character she was surpassed by none of 1 predecessors. The national age to which gave her name was one of the greatest in annals, and, in some respects, the most for nate in the history of any people. Her subject regarded her as time passed on with an exampled affection, of which the recollect lingers still like the afterglow of some sunset The influence of that sentiment all her peoples as one household The British Empire came to the consciousness of its before the close of that memorable reign, a if its political union should he cemented on the sceptre of his present Majesty the work federation will rise upon the foundations during the lifetime of our late Sovereign these reasons “Empire Day” throughout Colonies and in India is synonymous with Victoria Day. At home the efforts of L. Meath and his friends to secure the observation of May 24th as a national holiday are meet year by year with increasing success. Educational authorities in a number of districts agreed that an hour or two shall be devoted teaching British children, the citizens of. future, the nature of the “unequalled inheritance” of which it is one of our first duties make them the worthy heirs Here, at least an example which ought to be followed every school throughout the length breadth of the Empire, and let us hope the time will come when the definite teach of patriotism and the intelligent cultivation the sense of Imperial responsibility will promoted by the express direction of the State. No adequate steps are taken at home to the children of the people in the concept: of historic honor, national strength, Impeduty. Then we not infrequently complain t when these hoys and girls become men and women they do not show a sufficiently vigorous growth of the spirit which we have d nothing to implant in them. “Empire Day may in this respect become the means correcting one of the conspicuous defeat our character as an Imperial people, co-trust with the Colonies of an unparalleled dominate which it remains for us now to keep or give up."Nothing is more certain than that Mother Country and the Colonies can maintain their common interests against increasing pressure of a changing world thorough application of mind to the task. need a festival like “Empire Day” to help this purpose throughout the King’s domination by making the British peoples one in imperialism thought and sentiment upon at least one of the year. Englishmen have held their fortune upon such easy terms since Wate that they had almost ceased to remember recently that “past politics” were the hasi ‘present history.” We have been content remain without anything in the nature of Imperial fete-day. The Primrose League new example by securing the permanent observance of the anniversary of a states who had identified himself closely in national imagination with the idea of Empire Trafalgar Day, in its turn, was regarded sour disfavor by the Radical reaction as other fantastic innovation repugnant to fine old crusted habits of political thou upon which the Liberal party still re Since then the celebration of the memory of Nelson and of the greatest sea victory ever won has become with general acceptance a regular national event. But even Trafa Day does not adequately fill the irregular in the patriotic calendar. Almost every of modern people keeps the anniversary o delivrance from tyranny or of the achievement of its national union. We have nothing corresponds to the American Fourth of J and every citizen of the Republic will as us that the loss is ours, and that we miss opportunity of stirring the imagination of masses in devotion to the flag France her nationial fete upon July 14th, the anniversary of the storming of the Bastille since 1789 the Monarchists across the have had no festival which could compe inspiring associations with the birthday Revolution. Reunited Italy celebrates “Venti Settembre” when the Sardinian breached the walls of Rome. The Ge Empire in the same way commemorates i birth upon the anniversaries of the making battles of 1870. Let it be our hop will that “Empire Day’’ shall become i turn, sooner or later, the festival of the; ation between the Mother Country ar Colonies, involving common measures fo perial development, as well as common sures for Imperial defence, that shall coping-stone upon the solid structure of political union At present the day is kept public holiday in Canada, South Africa, ] and New Zealand, and in Australia it is ally, though not legally, recognised.Without the definite co operation of a parts of the Empire, represented, as we by the Imperial Council of the future, be impossible for Great Britain to maintain commercial and naval supremacy sir gleha or to extend to the Colonies and Indian impregnable protection that we give them Unionists who disagree with Mr. Chamb’ may refuse to think more Imperially that did before the historic Birmingham let them at least beware that they do not into the habit of thinking less Imperially before. There is some need for this was. We may disagree about the remedies applied. Thoughtful Englishmen cannot about the nature and the gravity problem to he approached, and, remember that sentiment is no substitute for construct policy, those who reject the fiscal so must propose, if they can, another meant making Empire Day the federal festival achieved Imperial union.

div.head: Alexandria and Cairo Bourses.
div.p: The Finance Ministry has granted the sum of £7,000 for the installation of a telephone line between the Alexandria and Cairo Bourses.

div.head: The Eldorado Theatre.
div.p: Four debuts are billed at the Eldorado theatre for this evening, namely Les de Bernys, duettists, the Sisters Dantes, Rosina de Franchi, and Lina Claris and Italia de Franchi.

div.head: The Census.
div.p: The criticisms as to the results of the taking of the census in Alexandria and Cairo are to the effect that there has been a most manifest lack of organisation as the increases of popula-tion in both cities are obviously far below, the actual figures.

div.head: Drowning Fatality at Boulao.
div.p: A native workman, engaged on board one of Cook’s boats at their Boulac works, fell overboard yesterday in an effort to save a plate which had slipped over the side. The man was drowned and his body was not
recovered until several hours later.

div.head: Pearl Pin Found.
div.p: We are requested by the secretary of the Alexandria Sporting Club to give notice that after the races held on Saturday afternoon a gold pin with a large “pearl drop” head was found. The same can *be obtained by the owner on application at the office of the “Egyptian Gazette,” Alexandria.

div.head: Plague Bulletin.
div.p: Sixteen fresh cases of plague have been announced during the last 24 hours of which eight cases have resulted fatally and two have been cured: the remainder are under treatment. The total number of cases this year is 639, of which 483 ended fatally, 95 recovered and 67 cases are still under treatment.

div.head: San Stefano Casino.
div.p: The opening ball of the San Stefano Casino, for subscribers only, will take place next Saturday evening, and on Sunday the afternoon orchestral concerts also will commence, concerts also being given on Sunday mornings. The subscription for one person for the season is P.T. 200, and for a family P.T. 350.

div.head: Double Execution
div.p: Ismail Said Ahmed, 40 years of age, and Mohamed Ahmed, 28 years of age, convicted, of having murdered Ibrahim Khalaf at Kafr el Dawar on January 18, were hung at Hadra prison this morning in the presence of Miralai Hopkinson Bey, Kaimakam Cobbe Bey, Hashem Bey, and a few Press representatives. Both men on the scaffold exclaimed “Ana Mazloum,” which may be freely interpreted as “I am wrongly condemned.”

div.head: Raid on Tramps.
div.p: We must congratulate the Greek Consulate in Cairo in having taken an excellent initiative by arresting 39 Greeks without employment. This might, with the best results, be followed by other Consulates. To the observer there are a sufficient number of ne’er-do-wells loafing round both Alexandria and Cairo, and, as has been seen by recent communications to the Press, some of these gentry are sufficiently undesirable.

div.head: Alexandria Archaeological Society.
div.p: The Society in accordance with an agreement made with the Administrator of the • Alexandria Municipality will shortly present its members with the new guide to the city and museum, which Professor Breccia has prepared on behalf of the Municipality. The members of the committee of the society elected for the year 1907-1908, are as follows: Mr. Amb. A. Ralli, Rear Admiral Blomfield, Dr. Schiess Pasha, Lady Blomfield, Mr. P. Chata-way. G. Norsa Bey, Mr. E. B. Gould, Dr. Osborne, Hamdoullah Emine Pasha, Poilay Bey, Simond Bey, and M. Malaval.

div.head: Union Artistique Francaise.
div.p: On Saturday, the above association gave a social evening party and concert, which was attended by a large number of members and guests. The programme was made up of vocal and instrumental items relieved here and there by domic recitations. Mr. Gateau, was not very happy in the choice of his monologues: he forgot he was not at a smoking concert, and the presence of a great many ladies in the audience should have made him more careful in the selection of his pieces. The various perfumers did their very best to entertain the friends who came to hear them, more especially Mr. Sikich, tenor, who although quite an amateur still untrained, sang with feeling and great earnestness. Mr. P. Levy is certainly endowed with humourous powers, which he used very successfully in bringing the concert to a close and filling the air with merriment The room was then cleared and a “sauterie” agreeably ended this friendly meeting. On the whole the organisers and members of the committee must have felt satisfied with the result of their efforts, and the association deserves credit for trying its best to please every one and gradually realize its purpose.

div.head: THE ABOUKIR COMPANY.
div.p: The accounts of the Aboukir Company for the year 1906 show a credit balance of £99,437, which, added to £33,468 brought forward, makes £132,906 : deducting the dividends of 7 per cent, which have been paid during the year on the old ordinary and deferred shares, and the bonus of £5 per share on the old ordinary £5 shares, there remains a balance to carry forward of £26,236.

The committee of the London Stock Exchange has ordered the following security to be quoted in the Official List : — Further issue of £20,500 five per cent, first debentures of £100 each, Nos. 936 to 1,140.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S SPEECH.HOME PRESS OPINION.
div.p: Lord Cromer’s farewell speech has made a profound impression upon the native population of Cairo. “For the first time,” says the “Timed,” “ he Egyptian people have heard, from Lord Cromer’s own lips, an account and a defence, of Lord Cromer’s policy. He has told them that be entered upon has task with two objects in view—the restoration of a good understanding with France and the introduction of a libera! spirit into a system of government ‘which, of necessity, is bureaucratic.’ He has witnessed the fulfilment of the first and he willingly leaves others to judge how far he has accomplished the second. He speaks with the scorn winch it merits of the allegation that, while the material prosperity of Egypt has been developed, her moral and* intellectual advance-ment has been neglected. He points to what has been achieved in the field of education, and he welcomes the ‘very competent and ex-has been achieved and he welcomes cellent ally’who has recently appeared in it." MORNING TOST.” Lord Cromer’s speech will long be remembered as one of those felicitous utterances which throw lighten the, secrets of statesmanship, while it does down the two the guiding mothonour to the man . He laid principal ends which have been motives of his policy, as the res-toration of a good understanding with France, and the moral and intellectual advancement of the Egyptian people. Both have been achieved The future is equally assured if the warning of the statesman who is now leaving Egypt, but whose voice in England cannot be lightly disregarded, is laid to heart by those who on a superficial acquaintance with the country would echange the ‘steady jog-trot’ of the experienced administrator for a reckless gallop.”

div.head: “STANDARD.”
div.p: “From first to last, the great Egyptian Consul has dealt faithfully, with the ’ trust committed to his charge ; in his own phrase, his policy has been simply ‘to tell the truth’ ; and his valedictory speech, charged though it is with warning, ends appropriately with a word of honest confidence and encouragement. Lord Cromer begs his successor to “Be of good cheer” ; and so he passes, full of honor and followed by the gratitude of two nations, to his late and hard-earned leisure.”

div.head: “DAILY TELEGRAPH.”
div.p: “The three hundred British troops that thronged the gallery represent the backbone of that steady, resolute, and fearless policy by which Lord Cromer extricated Egypt from bankruptcy and anarchy to a position which may well be envied by most of the great Powers. The presence and applause of the diplomatic representatives must have recalled to Cromer the innumerable single-handed fights he had successfully engaged in, when political intrigue arid financial jealousies were employed to defeat his single-minded purpose of putting Egypt on asound political and economic basis.”

div.head: RADICAL VIEWS.
div.p: “TRIBUNE.”
in his farewell speech at Cairo, justified a personal career which marked by the exercise of something

“Lord Cromer, abundantly justified has been marked approaching autocratic. power, and he right fully claims the gratitude of the Egyptian people for a splendid record of reforms accomplished in a land that was as corrupt as it was impoverished ”

div.head: "CHRONICLE.”
div.p: “If Lord Cromer had really been a king, say in the England (if 700 years ago, we may imagine how loudly history Would praise him. He would stand side by side with kings like Henry
IL or Edward must judge him. certainly
I, and it is as such that we Compared to his task, theirs not more arduous, and his
achievement has been at least as high. Like theirs, his qualities have been peculiarly English, but (if the best kind—integrity, patience, and reticence."

div.head: “DAILY NEWS.”
div.p: “Lord Cromer’s farewell to the country he has governed with such success and distinction was necessarily moving and touching occasion. In his retrospect of his long career he was able to point to triumphs of statesmanship and administrations of which nobody could have dreamt twenty years ago. . . . . .

But there remains one side of England’s work still unaccomplished, and Lord Cromer’s successor has to find the means of satisfying native ambitions that are not only honourable in themselves, but symptoms of the success we have gained ”

div.head: LAND AND MORTGAGE COMPANY OF EGYPT.
div.p: Mr. R. A. Huri has joined the board of the Land and Mortgage Company of Egypt in the place of Viscount Hampden, deceased.

It is announced that debenture interest coupons due on the 15th inst. of the Land and Mortgage Company of Egypt, and also the Debenture Bonds(drawn for redemption), will be paid on and after that date by Messrs. Barclay and Go.

div.head: SOCIETE COMMERCIALE D’EGYPTE.
div.p: Mr. Michel Sinadino, one of the founders of the Societe Commerciale d’Egypte and chairman of the Board of Directors of that Company, is retiring from active participation in the management of the Company after a connection of twenty two years

div.head: LORD CROMER’S RECEPTION. GREAT BRITAIN'S CONFIDENCE.
div.p: The great honours with which Lord Cromer’s arrival in London is to be marked have already been announced in our telegrams. The “Spectator” remarks.”

Owing to the unfortunate event of Lord Cromer’s health breaking down at a period of fierce agitation, they (the Egyptian people) are inclined to believe that Lord Cromer fell owing to want of support in England, and to believe also that the same fate awaits his successor. That being so, it is most important that not only the Government, bnt the whole of the British nation, should through some visible and public act show their continued confidence in Lord Cromer, and therefore in the policy which his successor is authorised by the British Government to maintain. It is not for us to suggest the method by which this most important fact should be emphasised, but we have little doubt that when the proper moment comes the King, acting, as he so often has acted before, as the representative of national feeling in its widest sense, will find the proper method of showing Egypt and the world how utterly ridiculous is the notion that Lord Cromer had lost the confidence of his Sovereign, of the Government, or of the British people. No doubt a vote of public money to Lord Cromer would have excellent result in this direction, but we venture to think that in addition to this some action of what we might call a more dramatic or spectacular kind, such as a public demonstration of welcome to Lord Cromer on his return home, is required.

div.head: KAMEL’S “RECKLESS POLICY.”
div.p: “MODERATE” REFORMERS’ DISAVOWAL.
In a letter to the “Times” on the Egyptian Nationalist movement, Mr. H. R. Fox Bourne, secretary of the Aborigines Protection Society, says :—

Allow me to point out to your readers that the main body of Egyptian reformers, w hose principal organs are “El Moayad” and “El Minbar”, are not in harmony with the reckless policy of Mustapha Kamel Pasha and his followers, whose organs are “El Lewa” and its English and French reproductions, the “Egyptian Standard” and the “Etendard Egyptien.” They aim, not at an overthrow of British control over Egypt, but at a gradual and statesmanlike development of internal self-government on the equitable lines started by Lord Dufferin and by the Organic Law of 1883, and repeatedly recommended and supported both by Mr. Gladstone’s and Lord Salisbury’s Governments. They recognize the splendid services rendered by Lord Cromer in promoting the material resources of Egypt, and the consequent improvement in many directions of the social condition of the people ; but they claim that the time has arrived for serious effort to be made towards solving what Sir Eldon Gorst, Lord Cromer’s successor, admits in his supplementary chapter to Lord Milner’s “England in Egypt,” to be “a problem of much greater complexity” ; and of which Sir Eldon says “The solution will be found rather in the development of the instincts of the people in the direction of local self-government than in the introduction of European institutions unsuited to the genius of the Oriental character."

div.head: THE KHARGA OASIS
div.p: AGRICULTURAL OPERATIONS

The following information is taken from the weekly reports Agricultural operations in the Oasis of Kharga are proceeding satisfactorily. Wheat and barley crops are now all reaped. The general average of the crops being satisfactory especially considering that most are on second year lands. The yield from one plot of 5 feddans of first cultivation was 40 ardebs or 8 ardebs to the feddan. The cotton crop is looking well, and the plants have had a first thinning.

The flow of the wells has increased since December last by an average of about 20 gallons per well per minute for the larger number of wells bored, all running simultaneously. This increase is probably due to greater economy in shutting down wells when not actually required for irrigation. The areas for rice and melon cultivation during the summer are now ready, and sowing is in progress. Some plots of melons well up.

Arrangements are in progress for the transport and sale of the coming date crop Remunerative contracts for the supply of stone in the Farshut district have been secured. These will materially diminish the cost of such cutting as has been necessary on the plateau.

div.head: YEMEN PEACE COMMISSION.
div.p: (From our own Correspondent).
Aden, May 8
The Yemen Peace Commission has arrived at Hodeida by special steamer and has left Sana.
Since I wrote you last the Turkish time Rediffs, who were* giving trouble to the people of Hodeida, have left.

div.head: Hamburg & Anglo-American Nile Company.
div.p: River Transport of Goods between Alexandria and Cairo.
Three Sailings a-week.
Agents at Alexandria
ALEXANDRIA BONDED WAREHOUSE CO. LTD.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLUB-
div.p: SECOND SUMMER MEETING.

Although the attendance was not so large as that of Monday, the second day’s racing of the Second Summer Meeting attracted a fair number on Saturday afternoon. Excellent weather prevailed and this combined with the fashionable gathering and interesting sport made one of the most enjoyable afternoons we have spent at the Sporting Club. In some measure this may be due to the exceptionally exciting result of the last race, but it is not usual to take the last first, and other races being worthy of mention we will take them in the order of running.

The May Selling Race brought out five runners, Sadik being favorite, and the judgment was not misplaced as it easily disposed of Moofid and Mizzaud. Only four horses went to the post for the Lord of Rosna Handicap amongst them the consistent and victorious Carlton. His top weight of 10 stone 7 did not stop him, and

his fourth consecutive race on this course this season. Digby tried hard with Aurelius but the effort was useless and could only finish a good second. Carlton we understand is being sent to England shortly. Stillwell shone in the next three races and performed the “hat trick” by winning each, his mounts being Ragueh, Fadaan, and El Tahawi. As we have already mentioned the surprise of the day was the May Handicap for which a field of nine runners turned out. Nadim was fancied and made favorite. All got away well and the excitement did not commence until entering the straight when Dounghan and Ghazi separating themselves from the rest, with Nadim joining them, made a neck and neck race. Shouts went up for Nadim, and Stillwell tried hard to add his fourth victory, but Jenkins was not to be beaten, just getting Doughan home by a very narrow margin. Even then so close was the result that until the numbers went up it was generally accepted that Nadim bad won.
To add to the surprise of the win the pari mutuel paid out what we believe to be the record price of P.T. 1416 or over L.E. 14 to the dollar.

Referring to the Pari Mutuel reminds ns of what seems to be a matter of general complaint viz :—the difficulty in the first place of being attended to in the scramble to make a bet, and secondly the extraordinary length of time it is necessary to wait before winnings can be drawn after a race, in some instances not until the next race is being or has been run. We realise the task of making the necessary check and calculations must be a huge one but surely the delay is detrimental to their own interests as one cannot be waiting at the windows, and betting on the next race at the same time, to say nothing of the inconvenience in perhaps having to miss the following race, and we think some method of improvement could be made in this direction, even in increasing their staff.
FIRST RACE, 3.30 p m.
May Selling Race of P.T. 5,000. For Arabs Horses 10.7. Galloways 10 3. Ponies 10.0. Winner to be sold for P.T. 10,000. Distance round the course. Entrance P.T. 250.

5 Runners. All got away well except Fantasia. Sadik took the lead only to be overtaken by Veteran who made the running until rounding the bend when Sadik came up and with Mizzand and Moofid made a good race resulting in a win for Sadik.

8 7. Digby. 2

4 Runners. Riado and Bonus made the running with Carlton lying well behind, until coming in sight round the bend, when Carlton had made up a lot of lost ground and came away, with Digby riding bird on Aurelius, but could only finish second to Carlton ; Riado tailed off.
Totalizator paid 1st P.T. 39.
Places P.T. 26, 25.

9 Runners.—A good start all being well bunch ed until entering the straight when Shour took the lead and looked a winner hut Stillwell brought El Tahawi ahead and won an exciting race with Shour second, bad third.
Totalisaton paid 1st P.T. 116.

Ibrahim Bey Cherif's c.a.p Kouzou, 10 3. Burnham. 0

9 Runners—A good start with Mashkour slightly to the lead, but was overtaken on the bend by Ghazi and Doughan near home Nadim joined them and an exciting race between these three resulted. Shoots went up for Nadim the heavily backed favorite who was coming at a big pace, but the victory went to the outsider Doughan well ridden by Jenkins.
Totalisator paid 1st P.T. 1416.
Places P.T. 72-21-43.
Mi-

div.head: MAKING THE SUEZ CANAL FREE.
div.p: Speaking at the Conference of Colonial Premiers and Ministers at the Colonial Office, Sir Joseph Ward, Premier of New Zealand, said that we ought to take a leaf out of the book of some of our rivals and assist shipping communications by subsidies. He would also, if he could, make the Suez Canal free, so as to prevent all obstacles to development. New Zealand would be prepared to take its part in providing the sum required. What he suggested might not be immediately feasible, but deserved consideration.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The exequatur, giving official recognition to Sir Eldon Gorst as H. B. M’.s Consul-General in Egypt, having arrived from Constantinople, Sir Eldon Gorst will be officially received by the Khedive at Ras el Tin Palace on Thursday.

I Saba Pasha will retire from active work as Postmaster General on the 1st. proxo. His Excellency, however, will not definitely leave the service of the Egyptian Government until the 15th September as he has leave up to that time.

A Cairo newspaper declares that Mustapha Pasha Fehmy, President of the Council of Minister, will shortly retire and will be replaced by Saad Pasha Zaghloul, the Minister of Education. This rumour is officially stated to he baseless.
M. G. Vasquez y Lopez-Amor, Spanish Consul at Port Said, has been transferred in the same capacity to Alexandria vice M. Spagnolo, deceased.
Mr. Edgers, chief inspector of Museums, has been granted three months’ leave to date from 4th June and Mr. Walsh, Sudan Irrigation Department, has been accorded three months' leave.
Mr. Percy Le Breton, the well-known barrister and son of Major Le Breton, leaves for Europe to-morrow on a well earned holiday.
Mr. H. Hesketh Bell, C.M G., K.M., commissioner for Uganda, is staying for a few days at Shepheard’s Hotel on his way to England.
M. Laloe, the recently appointed judge to the Cairo Mixed Tribunal, arrived in Cairo yesterday morning and took charge of his post ’
Mohamed Aly Scharara Bey, moudi of Keneh, and Moheb Pasha, Governor of the Suez Canal, have each obtained three months’ leave.
Messrs. George Le wis and J. B. Manson have been appointed temporary correspondents of the “Egyptian Gazette” at Cairo.

div.head: CITY AND AGRICULTURAL LAND OF EGYPT.
div.p: Registered May 1. £400,000 in 398,500 ordinary shares of £1 each and 30,000 deferred shares of Is. each. To adopt an agreement for the purchase of the Zogheb properties in Cairo, Place de l’Opera, and Rues El-Manakh, Kasr-el-Nil and Zogheb, on the terms set out in a contract between Messrs. Alexandre, Michel and Charles de Zogheb, and Madame Isabelle Michalla Pacha, of the one part, and Mesars. Clement Suares, Fils and Co., Count Fran-cesco Salimei, and Pietro Tonti, of the other part, to acquire, hold, develop, sell, let, or otherwise deal with land or other immovable property in Egypt, the Sudan, or elsewheie ; to lay out building sites; to erect, alter, demolish, decorate, fit, improve, and maintain buildings and conveniences; to cultivate, plant, pave, drain, or let on building lease or agree-ment any of the company’s land ; to advance money to and enter into contracts of any kind with builders, tenants, and others, and to carry on an investment, financial, and agency business. The signatories are :—A.Tilche, Alexandria, 250 ; J.E. de Menasce, Alexadria, 25) ; Pp. Salimei Francesco, Rome, proprietaire L. Adacher, 250; Ed Sasson, Alexandria, 250 ; F. Suares, Alexandria, 250; J. de Botton, Alexandria, five; V. Teissere, Alexandria, chief accountant de la Maison E. J. L. de Menasce, five. Minimum cash subscription, 0 per cent. of any shares offered to public. First directors (not less than three nor more than nine) : Baron Jacques E. de Menasce, Cav. Uff. A. Tilche, Count Francesco Salimei, and Edward Sasson. The first directors my appoint Count Michel de Zogheb as a director before the ordinary general meeting in 1908. They may also at any time appoint any other qualified person, subject to numerical limit, such director to hold office till the next ordinary general meeting and to be eligible for re-election. Qualification, 250 ordinary shares. Remuneration, 5 per cent, of the surplus profits after providing for special reserve fund and for the preferential dividend of 5 per cent. on the ordinary shares, divisible.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley (near Alexandria) half way to San Stefano
Ramleh's Fashionable Hotel.
Patronized by the Elite.
Full Pension P.T. 50 a day with Monthly Terms
Visitors from Cairo alight at Sidi Gaber.
Proprietor, C. AQUILINA, (Late of Thos Cook Sons)

div.head: BERLITZ SCHOOLS OF LANGUAGES
div.p: 236 BRANCHES.
French, German, Italian, Greek, Arabic, etc.
Private Lessons, Residence Lessons, taught by Native Masters

CAIRO : 1 Sharia Kamel.
